Findings.Title: IAM.5 MFA should be enabled for all IAM users that have console password
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether AWS Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is enabled for all AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) users that use a console password.

Findings.Title: SSM.2 EC2 instances managed by Systems Manager should have a patch compliance status of COMPLIANT after a patch installation
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether the compliance status of the Amazon EC2 Systems Manager patch compliance is COMPLIANT or NON_COMPLIANT after the patch installation on the instance. It only checks instances that are managed by AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager.

Findings.Title: ELBv2.1 Application Load Balancer should be configured to redirect all HTTP requests to HTTPS
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether HTTP to HTTPS redirection is configured on all HTTP listeners of Application Load Balancers. The control will fail if one or more HTTP listeners of Application Load Balancers do not have HTTP to HTTPS redirection configured.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: EFS.1 Elastic File System should be configured to encrypt file data at-rest using AWS KMS
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether Amazon Elastic File System (Amazon EFS) is configured to encrypt the file data using AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS). The check will fail if the encrypted key is set to false on DescribeFileSystems or if the KmsKeyId key on DescribeFileSystems does not match the KmsKeyId parameter.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Findings.Title: Lambda.2 Lambda functions should use latest runtimes
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks that the lambda function settings for runtimes, match the expected values set for the latest runtimes for each supported language. The latest runtimes this control checks for are: nodejs12.x, nodejs10.x, python3.8, python3.7, python3.6, ruby2.5, java11, java8, go1.x, dotnetcore2.1.

Findings.Title: 1.2 Ensure multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enabled for all IAM users that have a console password
Findings.Description: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) adds an extra layer of protection on top of a user name and password. It is recommended that MFA be enabled for all accounts that have a console password.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.3 Ensure credentials unused for 90 days or greater are disabled
Findings.Description: AWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials, such as passwords or access keys. It is recommended that all credentials that have been unused in 90 or greater days be removed or deactivated.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.8 Ensure rotation for customer created CMKs is enabled
Findings.Description: AWS Key Management Service (KMS) allows customers to rotate the backing key which is key material stored within the KMS which is tied to the key ID of the Customer Created customer master key (CMK). It is the backing key that is used to perform cryptographic operations such as encryption and decryption. It is recommended that CMK key rotation be enabled.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

ProductFields.aws/securityhub/annotation: AWS Config evaluated your resources against the rule. The rule did not apply to the AWS resources in its scope, the specified resources were deleted, or the evaluation results were deleted.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.16 Ensure IAM policies are attached only to groups or roles
Findings.Description: By default, IAM users, groups, and roles have no access to AWS resources. IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users, groups, or roles. It is recommended that IAM policies be applied directly to groups and roles but not users.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.4 Ensure access keys are rotated every 90 days or less
Findings.Description: Access keys consist of an access key ID and secret access key, which are used to sign programmatic requests that you make to AWS. It is recommended that all access keys be regularly rotated.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.6 Ensure S3 bucket access logging is enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket
Findings.Description: S3 Bucket Access Logging generates a log that contains access records for each request made to your S3 bucket. An access log record contains details about the request, such as the request type, the resources specified in the request worked, and the time and date the request was processed. It is recommended that bucket access logging be enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.6 Ensure S3 bucket access logging is enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket
Findings.Description: S3 Bucket Access Logging generates a log that contains access records for each request made to your S3 bucket. An access log record contains details about the request, such as the request type, the resources specified in the request worked, and the time and date the request was processed. It is recommended that bucket access logging be enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 3.9 Ensure a log metric filter and alarm exist for AWS Config configuration changes
Findings.Description: Real-time monitoring of API calls can be achieved by directing CloudTrail Logs to CloudWatch Logs and establishing corresponding metric filters and alarms. It is recommended that a metric filter and alarm be established for detecting changes to CloudTrail's configurations.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 3.14 Ensure a log metric filter and alarm exist for VPC changes
Findings.Description: Real-time monitoring of API calls can be achieved by directing CloudTrail Logs to CloudWatch Logs and establishing corresponding metric filters and alarms. It is possible to have more than 1 VPC within an account, in addition it is also possible to create a peer connection between 2 VPCs enabling network traffic to route between VPCs. It is recommended that a metric filter and alarm be established for changes made to VPCs.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Findings.Title: 3.13 Ensure a log metric filter and alarm exist for route table changes
Findings.Description: Real-time monitoring of API calls can be achieved by directing CloudTrail Logs to CloudWatch Logs and establishing corresponding metric filters and alarms. Routing tables are used to route network traffic between subnets and to network gateways. It is recommended that a metric filter and alarm be established for changes to route tables.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Findings.Title: 3.12 Ensure a log metric filter and alarm exist for changes to network gateways
Findings.Description: Real-time monitoring of API calls can be achieved by directing CloudTrail Logs to CloudWatch Logs and establishing corresponding metric filters and alarms. Network gateways are required to send/receive traffic to a destination outside of a VPC. It is recommended that a metric filter and alarm be established for changes to network gateways.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

ProductFields.aws/securityhub/annotation: Multi region CloudTrail with the required configuration does not exist in the account

StatusReasons.Description: Multi region CloudTrail with the required configuration does not exist in the account

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 3.11 Ensure a log metric filter and alarm exist for changes to Network Access Control Lists (NACL)
Findings.Description: Real-time monitoring of API calls can be achieved by directing CloudTrail Logs to CloudWatch Logs and establishing corresponding metric filters and alarms. NACLs are used as a stateless packet filter to control ingress and egress traffic for subnets within a VPC. It is recommended that a metric filter and alarm be established for changes made to NACLs.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

ProductFields.aws/securityhub/annotation: Multi region CloudTrail with the required configuration does not exist in the account

StatusReasons.Description: Multi region CloudTrail with the required configuration does not exist in the account

Findings.Title: 3.10 Ensure a log metric filter and alarm exist for security group changes
Findings.Description: Real-time monitoring of API calls can be achieved by directing CloudTrail Logs to CloudWatch Logs and establishing corresponding metric filters and alarms. Security Groups are a stateful packet filter that controls ingress and egress traffic within a VPC. It is recommended that a metric filter and alarm be established changes to Security Groups.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.5 Ensure AWS Config is enabled
Findings.Description: AWS Config is a web service that performs configuration management of supported AWS resources within your account and delivers log files to you. The recorded information includes the configuration item (AWS resource), relationships between configuration items (AWS resources), and any configuration changes between resources. It is recommended to enable AWS Config in all regions.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

It is recommended to enable AWS Config in all regions.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.1 Avoid the use of the "root" account
Findings.Description: The "root" account has unrestricted access to all resources in the AWS account. It is highly recommended that the use of this account be avoided.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: S3.4 S3 buckets should have server-side encryption enabled
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks that your Amazon S3 bucket either has Amazon S3 default encryption enabled or that the S3 bucket policy explicitly denies put-object requests without server side encryption.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 4.3 Ensure the default security group of every VPC restricts all traffic
Findings.Description: A VPC comes with a default security group whose initial settings deny all inbound traffic, allow all outbound traffic, and allow all traffic between instances assigned to the security group. If you don't specify a security group when you launch an instance, the instance is automatically assigned to this default security group. It is recommended that the default security group restrict all traffic.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: EC2.2 The VPC default security group should not allow inbound and outbound traffic
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks that the default security group of a VPC does not allow inbound or outbound traffic.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

It is recommended that the default security group restrict all traffic.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 4.1 Ensure no security groups allow ingress from 0.0.0.0/0 to port 22
Findings.Description: Security groups provide stateful filtering of ingress/egress network traffic to AWS resources. It is recommended that no security group allows unrestricted ingress access to port 22.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: IAM.1 IAM policies should not allow full "*" administrative privileges
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether the default version of AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies (also known as customer managed policies) do not have administrator access with a statement that has "Effect": "Allow" with "Action": "*" over "Resource": "*". It only checks for the Customer Managed Policies that you created, but not inline and AWS Managed Policies.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.22 Ensure IAM policies that allow full "*:*" administrative privileges are not created
Findings.Description: IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users, groups, or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is, granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks, instead of allowing full administrative privileges.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: IAM.1 IAM policies should not allow full "*" administrative privileges
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether the default version of AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies (also known as customer managed policies) do not have administrator access with a statement that has "Effect": "Allow" with "Action": "*" over "Resource": "*". It only checks for the Customer Managed Policies that you created, but not inline and AWS Managed Policies.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.22 Ensure IAM policies that allow full "*:*" administrative privileges are not created
Findings.Description: IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users, groups, or roles. It is recommended and considered a standard security advice to grant least privilege—that is, granting only the permissions required to perform a task. Determine what users need to do and then craft policies for them that let the users perform only those tasks, instead of allowing full administrative privileges.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.8 Ensure IAM password policy requires at least one number
Findings.Description: Password policies are, in part, used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure passwords are comprised of different character sets. It is recommended that the password policy require at least one number.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.13 Ensure MFA is enabled for the "root" account
Findings.Description: The root account is the most privileged user in an AWS account. MFA adds an extra layer of protection on top of a user name and password. With MFA enabled, when a user signs in to an AWS website, they will be prompted for their user name and password as well as for an authentication code from their AWS MFA device.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.20 Ensure a support role has been created to manage incidents with AWS Support
Findings.Description: AWS provides a support center that can be used for incident notification and response, as well as technical support and customer services. Create an IAM Role to allow authorized users to manage incidents with AWS Support.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: IAM.6 Hardware MFA should be enabled for the root user
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether your AWS account is enabled to use hardware multi-factor authentication (MFA) device to sign in with root credentials.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.14 Ensure hardware MFA is enabled for the "root" account
Findings.Description: The root account is the most privileged user in an AWS account. MFA adds an extra layer of protection on top of a user name and password. With MFA enabled, when a user signs in to an AWS website, they will be prompted for their user name and password as well as for an authentication code from their AWS MFA device. For Level 2, it is recommended that the root account be protected with a hardware MFA.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: IAM.4 IAM root user access key should not exist
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether the root user access key is available.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.9 Ensure VPC flow logging is enabled in all VPCs
Findings.Description: VPC Flow Logs is a feature that enables you to capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces in your VPC. After you've created a flow log, you can view and retrieve its data in Amazon CloudWatch Logs. It is recommended that VPC Flow Logs be enabled for packet "Rejects" for VPCs.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.9 Ensure VPC flow logging is enabled in all VPCs
Findings.Description: VPC Flow Logs is a feature that enables you to capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces in your VPC. After you've created a flow log, you can view and retrieve its data in Amazon CloudWatch Logs. It is recommended that VPC Flow Logs be enabled for packet "Rejects" for VPCs.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Effects/Data Exposure/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: S3.3 S3 buckets should prohibit public write access
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether your S3 buckets allow public write access by evaluating the Block Public Access settings, the bucket policy, and the bucket access control list (ACL).

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.6 Ensure IAM password policy requires at least one lowercase letter
Findings.Description: Password policies are, in part, used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure passwords are comprised of different character sets. It is recommended that the password policy require at least one lowercase letter.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.5 Ensure IAM password policy requires at least one uppercase letter
Findings.Description: Password policies are, in part, used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure passwords are comprised of different character sets. It is recommended that the password policy require at least one uppercase letter.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: IAM.7 Password policies for IAM users should have strong configurations
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether the account password policy for IAM users uses the following recommended configurations: RequireUppercaseCharacters: true, RequireLowercaseCharacters: true, RequireSymbols: true, RequireNumbers: true, MinimumPasswordLength: 14, PasswordReusePrevention: 24, MaxPasswordAge: 90.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.12 Ensure no root account access key exists
Findings.Description: The root account is the most privileged user in an AWS account. AWS Access Keys provide programmatic access to a given AWS account. It is recommended that all access keys associated with the root account be removed.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.11 Ensure IAM password policy expires passwords within 90 days or less
Findings.Description: IAM password policies can require passwords to be rotated or expired after a given number of days. It is recommended that the password policy expire passwords after 90 days or less.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.2 Ensure CloudTrail log file validation is enabled
Findings.Description: CloudTrail log file validation creates a digitally signed digest file containing a hash of each log that CloudTrail writes to S3. These digest files can be used to determine whether a log file was changed, deleted, or unchanged after CloudTrail delivered the log. It is recommended that file validation be enabled on all CloudTrails.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.2 Ensure CloudTrail log file validation is enabled
Findings.Description: CloudTrail log file validation creates a digitally signed digest file containing a hash of each log that CloudTrail writes to S3. These digest files can be used to determine whether a log file was changed, deleted, or unchanged after CloudTrail delivered the log. It is recommended that file validation be enabled on all CloudTrails.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Effects/Data Exposure/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: S3.2 S3 buckets should prohibit public read access
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether the following public access block settings are configured from account level: [ignorePublicAcls: true, blockPublicPolicy: true, blockPublicAcls: true, restrictPublicBuckets: true]

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.7 Ensure CloudTrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs
Findings.Description: AWS Key Management Service (KMS) is a managed service that helps create and control the encryption keys used to encrypt account data, and uses Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) to protect the security of encryption keys. CloudTrail logs can be configured to leverage server side encryption (SSE) and KMS customer created master keys (CMK) to further protect CloudTrail logs. It is recommended that CloudTrail be configured to use SSE-KMS.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Findings.Title: S3.2 S3 buckets should prohibit public read access

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub Foundational Security Best Practices documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.7 Ensure CloudTrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs
Findings.Description: AWS Key Management Service (KMS) is a managed service that helps create and control the encryption keys used to encrypt account data, and uses Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) to protect the security of encryption keys. CloudTrail logs can be configured to leverage server side encryption (SSE) and KMS customer created master keys (CMK) to further protect CloudTrail logs. It is recommended that CloudTrail be configured to use SSE-KMS.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: CloudTrail.2 CloudTrail should have encryption at-rest enabled
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether AWS CloudTrail is configured to use the server side encryption (SSE) AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) encryption. The check will pass if the KmsKeyId is defined.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.10 Ensure IAM password policy prevents password reuse
Findings.Description: IAM password policies can prevent the reuse of a given password by the same user. It is recommended that the password policy prevent the reuse of passwords.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.1 Ensure CloudTrail is enabled in all regions
Findings.Description: AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls for your account and delivers log files to you. The recorded information includes the identity of the API caller, the time of the API call, the source IP address of the API caller, the request parameters, and the response elements returned by the AWS service.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: CloudTrail.1 CloudTrail should be enabled and configured with at least one multi-region trail
Findings.Description: This AWS control checks that there is at least one multi-region AWS CloudTrail trail.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS-Foundational-Security-Best-Practices
Findings.Title: GuardDuty.1 GuardDuty should be enabled

Findings.Description: This AWS control checks whether Amazon Elastic Block Store snapshots are not publicly restorable.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.7 Ensure IAM password policy requires at least one symbol
Findings.Description: Password policies are, in part, used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure passwords are comprised of different character sets. It is recommended that the password policy require at least one symbol.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 1.9 Ensure IAM password policy requires minimum password length of 14 or greater
Findings.Description: Password policies are, in part, used to enforce password complexity requirements. IAM password policies can be used to ensure passwords are at least a given length. It is recommended that the password policy require a minimum password length 14.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.4 Ensure CloudTrail trails are integrated with CloudWatch Logs
Findings.Description: AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls made in a given AWS account. CloudTrail uses Amazon S3 for log file storage and delivery, so log files are stored durably. In addition to capturing CloudTrail logs within a specified S3 bucket for long term analysis, realtime analysis can be performed by configuring CloudTrail to send logs to CloudWatch Logs. It is recommended that CloudTrail logs be sent to CloudWatch Logs.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

Types: Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark
Findings.Title: 2.4 Ensure CloudTrail trails are integrated with CloudWatch Logs
Findings.Description: AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls made in a given AWS account. CloudTrail uses Amazon S3 for log file storage and delivery, so log files are stored durably. In addition to capturing CloudTrail logs within a specified S3 bucket for long term analysis, realtime analysis can be performed by configuring CloudTrail to send logs to CloudWatch Logs. It is recommended that CloudTrail logs be sent to CloudWatch Logs.

Recommendation.Text: For directions on how to fix this issue, please consult the AWS Security Hub CIS documentation.

ProductFields.aws/securityhub/annotation: The CloudTrail trail is not associated with any CloudWatch Logs log group ARN.
